Title: The entorhinal cortex of the monkey: II. Cortical afferents.
Abstract: The entorhinal cortex of the monkey is commonly viewed as the major link between the cerebral cortex and the other fields of the hippocampal formation. Until recently, however, little was known about the origins of the cortical projections to the entorhinal cortex, and most of the available information is still based on degeneration studies. We have carried out a systematic analysis of these connections by placing small injections of the retrograde tracer wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase into each of the fields of the entorhinal cortex of the Macaca fascicularis monkey. Retrogradely labeled cells were observed in several areas of the frontal and temporal lobes, the insula, and the cingulate cortex. In the frontal lobe, the greatest number of labeled cells were observed in the orbital region and specifically in areas 13 and 13a: labeled cells were also seen in areas 14, 11, and 12. In the dorsolateral frontal cortex, labeled cells were observed mainly in the rostral half of area 46; occasionally cells were also seen in areas 9, 8, and 6. In the cingulate cortex, labeled cells were observed in area 25, area 32, and rostral levels of area 24; fewer cells were observed at caudal levels of area 24 or in area 23. The retrosplenial region (areas 30 and 29), including its caudal extension along the rostral calcarine sulcus and its ventral extension into the temporal lobe, contained numerous labeled cells. In the temporal lobe, retrogradely labeled cells were arranged in two rostrocaudally oriented bands. Rostral to the hippocampal formation, the first band encompassed the piriform and periamygdaloid cortices and areas 35 and 36; the labeling in area 36 was continuous to the temporal pole. At more caudal levels this band was located immediately lateral to the hippocampal formation and included areas 35 and 36 rostrally and areas TH and TF caudally. The second band was situated in the superior temporal gyrus where labeled cells were observed in several distinct cytoarchitectonic fields, including the parainsular cortex in the fundus of the inferior limiting sulcus. In the insula proper, retrogradely labeled cells were seen mainly in the rostral or agranular division; far fewer were observed in the dysgranular and granular insula. Whereas there is little available physiological information concerning many of the cortical regions that project to the entorhinal cortex, on anatomical grounds they may be generally characterized as polysensory associational regions.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Region_Parcellation: Cingulate, Temporal, Frontal and Insular Cortex
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: " Criteria for placing areal cortical boundaries came from a variety of sources, including our own observations of a standard series of Nissl and fiber preparations. For the frontal lobe, the nomenclature of Walker ('40) was employed as slightly modified (Amaral and Price, '84). We attempted to employ the nomenclatures of Pandya and Sanides('73), Seltzer and Pandya('78), and Jones and Burton('76) for the fields of the superior temporal gyrus. Although we have been able to identify several distinct cytoarchitectonic fields in the superor temporal gyrus of the Macaca fascicularis, we were not able to directly apply any of the previous terminologies (which were originally defined for the rhesus monkey ) to these fields without substantial modifications in the definition of their cytoarchitectonic characteristics or location. The terminology  for the regions of heaviest retrograde labeling (the dorsal bank of the suoerior temporal gyrus ) is, therefore, based primarily on our own cyto- and myeloarchitectonic observations.we have used the terminology of Bonin and Bailey ('47) and Brodman ('09) with slight modifications (Amaral and Price '84, Amaral et al., 87) for the fields of the medial temporal lobe. For the insular cortex we have followed the divisions proposed by Jones and Burton ('76), and for the supratemporal plane we have employed a nomenclature similar to that of Merzenich and Brugge ('74).The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Pandya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85). " (p. 359)
@BrainMaps_Delineation.Comments:
Insausti et. al. say in this paper that they orientated to different and classic  nomenclature and parcellation schemes, but mostly they mixed them and combined them or added them, what they mostly described explicitly in their text.The citation above is only a small summary of cited parcellation schemes, because the authors explain their maps and their used single areas very detailed before they begin to describe the distribution of the label.
For this reason they created own unfolded maps to show the label distribution in areas with strict borders and names.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: Area 1 of IAC87a seems to be identical with area 1 of B09, because (i) both areas have the same location and (ii) B09 has  been cited already for the description of a cortical area in this paper.
Area G (gustatory cortex) of IAC87a seems to include area G ( second gustatory cortex) of Jones and Burton, because JB76 has been cited already for the description of a cortical area in this paper.

"On cytoarchitectonic grounds we recognized a rostral (area 36r) and caudal (area 36c) subdivision of area 36." (p. 372)"

"Area 36 also extends to the rostral surface of the temporal lobe and forms much of what Bonin and Bailey ('47) indicated to be area TG (Fig. 10). Moreover, we have recognized medial (area 36pm) and lateral (area 36pl) divisions of area 36p." (p. 378)

Areas 23 and 24 of IAC87a seem to be identical with areas 23 and 24 of PVM81, because (i) they have the same location, (ii) the same abbreviation and because (iii) PVM81 has been cited already for the description of the cingulate gyrus.

Areas 23 and 24 of IAC87a seem to be identical with areas 23 and 24 of PVM81, because (i) they have the same location, (ii) the same abbreviation and because (iii) PVM81 has been cited already for the description of the cingulate gyrus.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." (p. 359) " As previously described (Amaral and Price, '84), we have partitioned the ventral portion of the caudomedial frontal surface more in line with the original suggestions of Brodmann ('09). Thus, ventral and slightly rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum, we have recognized an area 25, which was labeled the infralimbic area by Brodmann ('09). ...Rostral to area 25 is a more highly laminated cortical field, which we have designated as area 32, or the prelimbic cortex of Brodmann ('09). Areas 25 and 32 have been previously described by Pandya et al. ('81)." (p. 369)

"The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." "The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." (p. 359) " The retrosplenial cortex encompasses three distinct fields, area 30 and medial and lateral parts of area 29, which extend caudal and ventral to the splenium of the corpus callosum (Vogt, 85). ...Area 29 extends slightly more rostral than area 30 and at these levels borders dorsally on the caudal part of area 24 and then on area 3. On cytoarchitectonic grounds, area 29 can be further partitioned into two fields,a medial part, area 29m, and a laterl part, area 29l, that correspond to areas 29d and 29a-c, respectively, of Vogt ('85)." (p. 369)

"The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." " (p. 378)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." (p. 359) " As previously described (Amaral and Price, '84), we have partitioned the ventral portion of the caudomedial frontal surface more in line with the original suggestions of Brodmann ('09). Thus, ventral and slightly rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum, we have recognized an area 25, which was labeled the infralimbic area by Brodmann ('09). ...Rostral to area 25 is a more highly laminated cortical field, which we have designated as area 32, or the prelimbic cortex of Brodmann ('09). Areas 25 and 32 have been previously described by Pandya et al. ('81)." (p. 369)

"The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." "The nomenclature for the cingulate cortex has been derived from the works of Panfya et al. ('81) and Vogt ('85)." (p. 359) " The retrosplenial cortex encompasses three distinct fields, area 30 and medial and lateral parts of area 29, which extend caudal and ventral to the splenium of the corpus callosum (Vogt, 85). ...Area 29 extends slightly more rostral than area 30 and at these levels borders dorsally on the caudal part of area 24 and then on area 3. On cytoarchitectonic grounds, area 29 can be further partitioned into two fields,a medial part, area 29m, and a laterl part, area 29l, that correspond to areas 29d and 29a-c, respectively, of Vogt ('85)." (p. 369)

@Injections.Citation: " Experiments IM-1 and IM-3 had very similar injections located in the rostral portion of EC. Both also involved EI with IM-3 extending somewhat more rostrally than IM-1. In experimant IM-1, the focus of the injection was located medially in the enthorhinal cortex; the parasubiculum was also involved in the injection and diffuse labeling extended into presubiculum." (p. 362)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In general, the distribution of the retrogradely labeled cells on the contralateral side was identical to that on the ipsilateral side (though the numbers of labeled cells were generally lower), and all labeled cells were located in layer III." (p. 389)

" In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). In certain fields that demonstrated dense retrograde labeling, such as area TF of the parahippocampal gyrus (see Fig. 18c), cells were also observed in all other layers." (p. 363)

@Injections.Citation: " Experiments IM-1 and IM-3 had very similar injections located in the rostral portion of EC.Both also involved EI with IM-3 extending somewhat more rostrally than IM-1. .... The injection in IM-3 was larger and less confined than the one in IM-1. It extended somewhat more laterally than IM-1 but did not reach the rhinal sulcus.There was substantial leakage of tracer along the pipette track, but this was confined to other fields of the hippocampal formation. " (p. 362)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). " In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). @Injections.Citation: " ... EO was involved in a much larger injection (IM-4), which was centered in the periamygdaloid cortex. The focus of this injection was located at approximately the midrostrocaudal level of the amygdala and heavily involved the periamygdaloid cortex, the anterior cortical nucleus, and the medial nucleus." (p. 362)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). In certain fields that demonstrated dense retrograde labeling, such as area TF of the parahippocampal gyrus (see Fig. 18c), cells were also observed in all other layers." (p. 363)

@Injections.Citation: " There were 2 experiments in which the injections  were confined to ER and ELr. The rostral of the 2 (IM-6) was centered at the midrostrocaudal level of ER and involved much of the transverse extent of the enthorhinal cortex. ... The other  injection (IM-8) was located in the caudal portion of ER in a mediolateral position similar to that of IM-6. There was no leakage of the tracer along the pipette track, and the injection, in this case, appeared to be totally confined to the enthorhinal cortex. " (p. 362)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). " In general, the distribution of the retrogradely labeled cells on the contralateral side was identical to that on the ipsilateral side (though the numbers of labeled cells were generally lower), and all labeled cells were located in layer III." (p. 389)

@Injections.Citation:
The injection in experiment IM-7 heavily involved the lateral aspect of the transitional region between EI and EC. It was centered at a level just caudal to the rostral pole of the
hippocampus. The injection did not reach the rhinal sulcus, so ELc was only slightly involved." (p. 362)

@Injections.Citation: " To determine which cortical labeling might have resulted from the inadvertent involvement of fibers directed to the subicular complex, we placed an injection into the subicular complex (DM-44)  at a level similar to that in case DM-45. The injection was somewhat smaller (50 nl) than the entorhinal injections, was focused over the subiculum proper, and also involved the lateral half of the presubiculum. ... The entorhinal cortex at the level of the injection (the transition between EC and ECL) was not included in the injection. " (p. 362)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). @Injections.Citation: " The injection in experiment DM-45 was of fast blue rather than WGA-HRP. It was centered in the lateral half of the rostral portion of EC and was completely confined to the enthorhinal cortex with no leakage into the overlying fields of the hippocampal formation." (p. 362)

@Injections.Citation: " The injection in experiment M-4-86 involved the medial half of caudal EI. In this respect it is complementary to the injection in case IM-7. The injection in M-4-86 continued caudally into the dorsomedial tip of EC and ECL. The presubiculum and paraubiculum through these levels were also heavily involved by the injection, although there was no extrahippocampal diffusion of the tracer." (p. 362)

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " In each of the cortical fields that project to the entorhinal cortex, most of the retrogradely labeled cells were found in layer III, and they invariably had the appearance of pyramidal cells (see Figs. 17, 18). " (p. 362)

publication.title: The entorhinal cortex of the monkey: II. Cortical afferents.
publication.abstract: The entorhinal cortex of the monkey is commonly viewed as the major link between the cerebral cortex and the other fields of the hippocampal formation. Until recently, however, little was known about the origins of the cortical projections to the entorhinal cortex, and most of the available information is still based on degeneration studies. We have carried out a systematic analysis of these connections by placing small injections of the retrograde tracer wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase into each of the fields of the entorhinal cortex of the Macaca fascicularis monkey. Retrogradely labeled cells were observed in several areas of the frontal and temporal lobes, the insula, and the cingulate cortex. In the frontal lobe, the greatest number of labeled cells were observed in the orbital region and specifically in areas 13 and 13a: labeled cells were also seen in areas 14, 11, and 12. In the dorsolateral frontal cortex, labeled cells were observed mainly in the rostral half of area 46; occasionally cells were also seen in areas 9, 8, and 6. In the cingulate cortex, labeled cells were observed in area 25, area 32, and rostral levels of area 24; fewer cells were observed at caudal levels of area 24 or in area 23. The retrosplenial region (areas 30 and 29), including its caudal extension along the rostral calcarine sulcus and its ventral extension into the temporal lobe, contained numerous labeled cells. In the temporal lobe, retrogradely labeled cells were arranged in two rostrocaudally oriented bands. Rostral to the hippocampal formation, the first band encompassed the piriform and periamygdaloid cortices and areas 35 and 36; the labeling in area 36 was continuous to the temporal pole. At more caudal levels this band was located immediately lateral to the hippocampal formation and included areas 35 and 36 rostrally and areas TH and TF caudally. The second band was situated in the superior temporal gyrus where labeled cells were observed in several distinct cytoarchitectonic fields, including the parainsular cortex in the fundus of the inferior limiting sulcus. In the insula proper, retrogradely labeled cells were seen mainly in the rostral or agranular division; far fewer were observed in the dysgranular and granular insula. Whereas there is little available physiological information concerning many of the cortical regions that project to the entorhinal cortex, on anatomical grounds they may be generally characterized as polysensory associational regions.
